pullRequest.title: Remove concept of namespaces and LogicalPersistentStore.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Goals (and why):
Based on comments from #4521 there are certain steps which make more sense to be done in a separate PR. Make the semantics more consistent with the usage and remove redundant classes. Makes the code cleaner and the following PR more manageable. The main concept change is the introduction of the Handle. Also the PersistentStore now has to store ByteString.
Implementation Description (bullets):

PhysicalPersistentStore is now a generic PersistentStore<K, V>
StoreNamespace is now PersistentStore.Handle

Testing (What was existing testing like?  What have you done to improve it?):

existing tests should cover the changes

Concerns (what feedback would you like?):

are there some nits I missed

Where should we start reviewing?:

PersistentStore

Priority (whenever / two weeks / yesterday):

today would be ideal

nodes.bodyText: I think it'll suffice to just call it Handle. Since we'll more often than not refer to it as PersistentStore.Handle which makes sense by itself.
Similar to how Map refers to Map.Entry within its class, you should refer to Handle as PersistentStore.Handle everywhere in this interface, and also in the implementations that have already had this.

This javadoc is somewhat roundabout and doesn't say anything that makes me understand what a handle is, and what calling `createHandle`` multiple times does internally. i.e. I can get multiple handles but are they to the same "door" so to speak? Or are they handles to different "doors". From earlier conversation it's the latter, but it's not super clear here.
The type is not relevant, you can see it in the method signature.
Maybe something like: "createSpace" where space is described as a newly initialised place to put data or something along those lines, @gmaretic what do you think?

+package com.palantir.atlasdb.persistent.api;

+import java.util.List;
+import java.util.Map;

+import java.util.UUID;

+public interface PersistentStore<K, V> extends AutoCloseable {
+    @Value.Immutable
+    interface EntryFamilyHandle {
+        UUID uniqueName();
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Gets the value associated with the entry specified by {@code key}.
+     *
+     * @param entryFamilyHandle handle to the entry family from which we want to retrieve the value
+     * @param key                entry key for which we want to retrieve the value
+     * @return the {@link Optional} containing the value or empty if there is no associated value
+     * @throws SafeIllegalArgumentException when {@code entryFamilyHandle} is a handle to a non existing entry family
+     */
+    Optional<V> get(EntryFamilyHandle entryFamilyHandle, @Nonnull K key);
+
+    /**
+     * Gets the values associated with the entries specified by {@code keys}.
+     *
+     * @param entryFamilyHandle handle to the entry family from which we want to retrieve the values
+     * @param keys               representing keys for which we want to retrieve the values
+     * @return a map from keys to values
+     */
+    Map<K, V> get(EntryFamilyHandle entryFamilyHandle, List<K> keys);
+
+    /**
+     * Stores the {@code value} for the associated {@code key} while overwriting the existing value in the specified
+     * {@code entryFamilyHandle}.
+     *
+     * @param entryFamilyHandle of the store to which we should store the entry
+     * @param key                entry key
+     * @param value              entry value
+     * @throws SafeIllegalArgumentException when {@code entryFamilyHandle} is a handle to a non existing entry family
+     */
+    void put(EntryFamilyHandle entryFamilyHandle, @Nonnull K key, @Nonnull V value);
+
+    /**
+     * Stores the entry pairs given in {@code toWrite}, overwriting the existing values.
+     *
+     * @param entryFamilyHandle of the store to which we should store the entry
+     * @param toWrite            entry pairs to write
+     * @throws SafeIllegalArgumentException when {@code entryFamilyHandle} is a handle to a non existing entry family
+     */
+    void put(EntryFamilyHandle entryFamilyHandle, Map<K, V> toWrite);
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a handle of type {@link EntryFamilyHandle} to the underlying store. Each call returns a new {@link

nodes.bodyText: nit: move this next to cacheDescriptor.currentSize...
change the name of this class.
Can we just bite the bullet and call this rocks, either that or do the "generification" properly. The mix of the two is inconsistent and quite confusing. Probably a separate PR however.
let's pair tomorrow, I'd like to clarify what this means
nit: probably implied, but should say Keys which are not present in the store will not be included in the returned map.

+public interface PersistentStore<K, V> extends AutoCloseable {
+    /**

+     */

+
+    /**
+     * Gets the values associated with the entries specified by {@code keys}.
+     *
+     * @param handle handle to the store space

+
+    /**

+     * store space.
+     *

+    /**
+     * Creates a store space to be used to store key-value pairs. Each call creates a new store space.
+     *
+     * @return handle to the created store space
+     */
+    PersistentStore.Handle createSpace();
+
+    /**
+     * Drops the store spacey specified by the supplied handle. Dropping of a store space may fail if there are
+     * concurrent calls on the same store space or if the store space has already been dropped.
+     *

nodes.bodyText: typos
put serde inside the thing that's actually talking to persistent store
Wasn't this class supposed to be generic? Bit confused here. Also deserializeValue key needs to be ByteString.
you probably want two separate things, one that's a ByteString-> Long entry mapper, and the other that's a Long,Long to Long,Long which "deserialises" the delta encoding.

+import com.palantir.logsafe.Preconditions;

+import okio.ByteString;
+
+/**
+ * Stores timestamps using delta encoding for commit timestamp.
+ */
+public class TimestampsEntryMapper implements OffHeapTimestampCache.EntryMapper {

nodes.bodyText: this should be a separate method, I initially thought this would be a thing that's called as a refreshable (which is weird). Then refer to it via a method reference.
just use id.
also have a static method that creates a new Handle by generating a random uuid.

nit:
assertThatNullPointerException()
  .isThrownBy(() -> ...);
reads a bit better from left to right top to bottom

it's not sufficient to test it like this, because there's nothing that says that the delta encoding is correct, only that when you serialise and deserialise it's correct.
You want something along the lines of a mock of the LongEntryMapper which receives delta encoded inputs, etc.

on second thought this is weird, a persistent store is a property of a particular timestamp cache, to get things setup correctly you have a weird ternary setup. If you're going to put the timestamp store through which requires manual wiring, then you might as well setup the timestamp cache properly.
